question:
QUESTION:

How do we prove that a number is an integer?
answer:
ANSWER:

If you're just looking at a number, say 7, you can just say that it is an integer. But if it is a more abstract quantity (such as the product/sum of other numbers/variables), then some sort of justification based on the closure of integers would suffice.

For example, suppose I want to show that $$k = 2x + y$$ is an integer. And suppose we know that $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers, then you could just say that $$k$$ is an integer because $$x$$ and $$y$$ are integers and the integer set is closed under addition and multiplication.

question:
QUESTION:

Hi!


I just got a bit confuse on the way that the proof on 2.sp2 was done for ((A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A ). I understood all the mathematical computations on why x (an arbitrary element) belongs to A, but got stuck on the reasoning why by given that x ∈ A and x ∈ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B),  (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ⊆ A  must be true. Why couldn't it be the other way around where A ⊆ (A \ B) ∪ (A ∩ B) ? 

Thanks in advance!
answer:
ANSWER:

Well that conclusion is being made because we are under the case of showing that $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$. Remember, to show equality, we show inclusion in both directions. So focusing on the direction $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B) \subseteq A$$, we would want to show that for any element that appears in the left hand side, it must also appear in the right hand side. 2.sp2 argues that for any element $$x \in (A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$, we have $$x \in A$$, so we have that any element in the left hand side also appears in the right hand side (since x was arbitrary), and by definition of subset, we conclude that the left hand side is a subset of the right hand side. 

We then go on to show the inclusion in the other direction. And to show that, we would go about taking an arbitrary element of $$A$$ and show that it appears in $$(A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)$$.

I think the key thing to note is the definition of subset. We have $$A \subset B$$ if and only if for every element $$a \in A$$, we also have $$a \in B$$. That's what we are doing in the set proofs; we consider an element $$a \in A$$ and then show that it must be that $$a \in B$$ and then conclude that $$A \subseteq B$$

question: QUESTION:
answer:
ANSWER:

In one sentence: Stars and bars is an application of simple combinations.

For more detail, with simple combinations, such as $$\binom{n}{r}$$, we are simply considering a set of $$n$$ distinct items and determining how many ways can we choose $$r$$ of these items. Equivalently, this counts the number of subsets of size $$r$$ from our original set.

Stars and bars can be thought of as a two step procedure. We see a direct correlation between distributing indistinguishable items to distinguishable containers with an arrangement of stars and bars. So to count the number of ways to distribute, we count the number of arrangements of stars and bars. Suppose we have $$n$$ stars and $$r-1$$ bars, then our procedure would begin by choosing $$n$$ locations to put the stars. Since the remaining open slots must be filled with bars, they can only be filled in one way. So by MR, you get the familiar equation for stars and bars which is $$\binom{n + r - 1}{n}$$, or equivalently, $$\binom{n+r-1}{r-1}$$

question:
QUESTION:

I don't really understand what example 1,2  means - is there a more concrete explanation/example for this? Also, what is g(f) and h(f) for the question below?
answer:
ANSWER:

g and h are examples of functions that have the domain $$B^A$$ and codomain $$2^C$$. So the domain of g and h are functions and the codomain of g and h are subsets of [1..n].

A good question is what is the size of the domain? And what is the size of the codomain? 

The domain has size $$n^n$$ and the codomain has size $$2^n$$. 

To understand the function $$g$$, consider an arbitrary function $$\phi: [1..n] \rightarrow [1..n]$$. Note that $$\phi \in [1..n]^{[1..n]}$$, so it is in the domain. Note that $$\phi$$ takes as input $$x \in [1..n]$$ and outputs some $$y \in [1..n]$$. That is, $$\phi(x) = y$$ where $$x, y \in [1..n]$$.

When evaluating $$g(\phi)$$, we note that the mapping is defined by $$\{x | f(x) = 1\}$$ where $$x \in [1..n]$$. Therefore, the mapping is looking at all elements of $$[1..n]$$ such that when $$\phi$$ acts on that element, the output is $$1$$. These elements form a subset of $$[1..n]$$. How exciting! Let's call this subset $$A$$. That is, we have $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ and $$\forall a \in A$$, we have $$\phi(a) = 1$$. 

Then, $$g(\phi) = A$$.

For function $$h$$, we do something similar, but now $$h$$ maps $$\phi$$ to its range (which is also a subset of $$[1..n]$$). 

For the last part of the question, we are given $$f$$ as the identity function. This means, $$\forall x \in [1..n]$$ we have $$f(x) = x$$. We want to compute $$g(f)$$. This is equivalent to asking: "What is the set $$A \subseteq [1..n]$$ such that $$\forall a \in A$$ we have $$f(a) = 1$$?". Well, if $$f$$ is the identity, then it must be that $$A = \{1\}$$. Therefore, $$g(f) = \{1\}$$.

For $$h(f)$$ we ask ourselves, "if $$f$$ is the identity function, what is $$Ran(f)$$?". Well, this is just $$[1..n]$$. So, we have $$h(f) = [1..n]$$

J is just an arbitrary subset of $$[1..n]$$. It basically narrows down which values we are focusing on (of whether or not they are in the right position) in the permutation.

Are these two different definitions? If so, can you explain the difference?

ANSWER:

Two sets are said to be disjoint if they share no elements in common. That is, $$A$$ and $$B$$ are disjoint when $$A \cap B = \emptyset$$. The term "pairwise disjoint" has a definition that builds off the definition of "disjoint". We say a collection of sets $$A_1, A_2, ..., A_n$$ are pairwise disjoint when $$\forall i, j$$, we have $$A_i \cap A_j = \emptyset$$.

question: QUESTION: Why are we solving for when we are returning the ith pair of sock? How does this lead us to find the expected pair of socks
answer:
ANSWER:

The total amount of socks being returned can be thought of as a sum of a bunch of $$1$$'s and $$0$$'s, where a 1 indicates if the sock has been returned and a 0 otherwise. For example, suppose we put in 3 pairs of socks (we'll label these pairs A, B, and C) and only received 2 back. And further, suppose that we didn't receive pair B back. Then, it is true that we received 1 + 0 + 1 = 2 pairs back (1 for A and 1 for C). This is essentially what indicators are. So if we were to define an indicator for each pair of socks, and sum them all together, we would get the total amount of pairs returned.

Thus, if $$S = I_1 + I_2 + ... + I_n$$, then $$\mathbb{E}[S] = \mathbb{E}[I_1 + I_2 + ... + I_n]$$. And by using Linearity of Expectation, we have this being equal to $$\mathbb{E}[I_1] + \mathbb{E}[I_2] + ... + \mathbb{E}[I_n] = \sum_{i=1}^n \mathbb{E}[I_i]$$.

So our problem has been reduced to finding the expected value of an indicator, where the indicator is whether or not the $$i$$th pair is returned. By finding this value, we can easily obtain $$\mathbb{E}[S]$$ using the math above.

QUESTION:

For example, I may have a probability space $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ where I'm rolling 2023 dice. But let's say I want to focus on the first 10 dice. Can I define $$(\omega, Pr)$$ within $$(\Omega, Pr)$$ to "zoom in"? Or should I say these are two separate probability spaces?
answer:
ANSWER:

the short answer is "probably". The long answer would require a lot more conversation about what you are intending to do by "focusing" on the first 10 dice rolls. 

In general, I would try to avoid a "sub-probability space" and rather just define an event. Most ideas I can think of that involve "focusing on the first 10 dice" can be solved by just defining an event and giving its corresponding probability.

For example, I could define $$E$$ to be the event that the first 10 dice rolls are all even numbers. And this would be a perfectly fine event definition since $$E \subseteq \Omega$$. And then we could go about computing $$Pr[E]$$ in whichever way fancies us.

ADDENDUM: In general when we "restrict" the sample space like this we need to show that the new probability problem is equivalent to the old problem.

QUESTION:

Is this a wrong method? Also, if it is not explicitly stated, can we still write answers in open form? How would we write the below answer in closed form? Thank you
answer:
ANSWER:

Yes this is a valid solution. You can simplify this by first noting, from Pascal's triangle, that:

$$\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + ... + \binom{2n}{2n} = 2^{2n}$$.

Then, we see that $$\binom{2n}{0} = \binom{2n}{2n}$$, $$\binom{2n}{1} = \binom{2n}{2n-1}$$, etc. so the above simplifies to:

$$(\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{2n}) + (\binom{2n}{1} + \binom{2n}{2n-1}) + ... + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$

$$2 \cdot \binom{2n}{0} + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{1} + ... + 2 \cdot \binom{2n}{n-1} + \binom{2n}{n} = 2^{2n}$$

$$2 \cdot \left( \binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} \right) = 2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}$$.

And thus, $$\binom{2n}{0} + \binom{2n}{1} + \ldots + \binom{2n}{n-1} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}$$.

So then your final answer would become $$\frac{\frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2}}{2^{2n}} = \frac{2^{2n} - \binom{2n}{n}}{2^{2n+1}}$$ which is the correct answer.

Your answers should always be in closed form unless we explicitly mention that open form solutions are allowed.

Why exactly can we conclude that Pr[X <= (a+b)/2] = Pr[X=a] when a < (a+b)/2?
answer:
ANSWER:

Because $$\mathrm{Val}(X) = \{a, b\}$$, which means that for any $$\alpha \neq a, b$$, we would have $$\Pr[X = \alpha] = 0$$. Therefore, to calculate $$\Pr[X \leq \frac{a+b}{2}]$$, we can take the following sum:

$$\Pr[X \leq \frac{a+b}{2}] = \sum_{\alpha \leq \frac{a+b}{2}} \Pr[X = \alpha]$$. But all of these probabilities will be $$0$$ except when $$\alpha = a$$. So the sum reduces to $$\Pr[X = a]$$.

question:
QUESTION:

Hi! I was just wondering how we got from n! - | B1 u B2 ... u Bn | to the final equation of the form n! (1 - 1/1! ... + (-1)^n/n!). Thank you so much!!
answer:
ANSWER:

We are just doing PIE to get the parenthetical part. We have:

$$|B_1 \cup ... \cup B_n| = \sum_i |B_i| - \sum_{i, j} |B_i \cap B_j| + \sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| - \ldots + \sum_{1..n} |B_1 \cap B_2 \cap ... \cap B_n|$$

Consider, for example, the third summation of $$\sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k|$$. In words, for a single $$i, j, k$$, we have that $$B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k$$ being the permutations in which $$h_i$$ does appear in position $$i$$, $$h_j$$ does appear in position $$j$$, and $$h_k$$ does appear in position $$k$$.

To find this cardinality, we do a simple counting procedure:

Step 1: Place $$h_i, h_j, h_k$$ in positions $$i, j, k$$ respectively (1 way)

Step 2: Arrange the remaining elements ($$(n-3)!$$ ways)

So for a single $$i, j, k$$, we have $$|B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| = (n-3)!$$. For the summation term , we have $$\sum_{i, j, k} |B_i \cap B_j \cap B_k| = \sum_{i, j, k} (n-3)!$$. The question is, how many $$i, j, k$$ triples are there? Well, there are $$\binom{n}{3} = \frac{n!}{3!(n-3)!}$$.

So this summation term reduces to $$\frac{n!}{3!(n-3)!} \cdot (n-3)! = \frac{n!}{3!}$$.

You can do a similar thing for all of the other summations, plug it back into the PIE equation, and factor out an $$n!$$, and you will get the desired expression.

question:
QUESTION:

I am confused because for (a) - this is not a conditional probability? How do you define "all the other cards you drew are aces, twos, threes, or fours" as a separate event from "event that you draw 4 of spades"?
answer:
ANSWER:

You could solve this using conditional probability.

Let A be the event that the 12 other cards in your hand are Ace, 2, 3, 4. Let B be the event that you drew the 4 of spades.

Then, $$\Pr[A | B] = \frac{\Pr[A \cap B]}{\Pr[B]} = \frac{\frac{|A \cap B|}{|\Omega|}}{\frac{|B|}{|\Omega|}} = \frac{|A \cap B|}{|B|}$$.

To calculate $$|A \cap B|$$, we need to find the number of hands that have the 4 of spades and all the remaining cards are Aces, 2, 3, 4. Consider the counting procedure:

Step 1: Include the 4 of spades in your hand.

Step 2: Out of all remaining possible Aces, 2's, 3's and 4's, choose 12 cards to include in your hand.

Step 1 can be performed in 1 way. Step 2 can be performed in $$\binom{15}{12}$$ ways. So by MR, $$|A \cap B| = \binom{15}{12}$$.

To calculate $$|B|$$, we need the number of hands that have the 4 of spades.

Step 1: Include the 4 of spades.

Step 2: Choose 12 remaining cards.

Step 1 can be performed in 1 way. Step 2, since there are 51 cards left to choose from, can be performed in $$\binom{51}{12}$$ ways.

Substitute, and we get the same answer.

question:
QUESTION:

The question in the video is:

How many cycles of length 4 are there in $$~K_4$$?

How is the correct answer of 15 obtained?
answer:
ANSWER:

Let $$K_5 = (V, E)$$ where $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4, v_5\}$$ and $$(v_i, v_j) \in E \quad \forall i, j$$.

Step 1: Choose 4 vertices. This can be done in $$\binom{5}{4}$$ ways.

Suppose, WLOG, the vertices we chose were $$v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4$$. 

Step 2: Create a cycle out of them. We can do this in three ways:

1. $$v_1 - v_2 - v_3 - v_4$$

2. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_2 - v_4$$

3. $$v_1 - v_3 - v_4 - v_2 $$.

By MR, we have: $$\binom{5}{4} \cdot 3 = 15$$

question: QUESTION: how do we know whether we should induct on vertices or edges?
answer:
ANSWER:

What you induct on really depends on the problem. Also, both induction on edges and induction on vertices have their own separate issues, so it just depends.

For example, inducting on vertices can sometimes be annoying because when you remove a vertex, you also have to remove all incident edges. But at the same time, inducting on vertices can be nice when you can guarantee existence of a specific type of vertex in a graph (i.e a leaf in a tree)

What's nice about edge induction is that when you remove an edge, you don't have to remove any vertices, but removing edges can disconnect the graph, and removing edges in general may not be as easy to generalize as removing vertices.

question:
QUESTION:

In a tree $$G=(V,E)$$ (undirected), adding one more edge will result in a cycle, by the minimally acyclic property (and hopefully we don't have to prove this on the final...?). Following this logic, do we know that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1? If so, do we have to prove it, and how might we approach this proof?

Related, if a connected undirected graph with $$n$$ vertices has exactly $$k$$ cycles, does such a graph have exactly $$k$$ extra edges compared to its spanning tree?

This question is inspired by Final Review Q11 for reference
answer:
ANSWER:

It is NOT true that with each edge we add, the number of cycles in $$G$$ will increase by exactly 1. Take, for example, $$G = (V, E)$$ with $$V = \{v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4\}$$ and $$E = \{(v_1, v_2), (v_2, v_3), (v_3, v_4)$$. This graph is a tree with zero cycles. Adding the edge $$(v_4, v_1)$$ creates a single cycle. However, if we were to add another edge (while still including $$(v_4, v_1)$$), say $$(v_1, v_3)$$, then the resulting graph has $$3$$ cycles.

It follows that the answer to your "related" question is no.
